attributes.title: Is news to blame? Analyzing the effects of “news vacation” on affective polarization and other outcomes

q1.value: Is news to blame? Analyzing the effects of “news vacation” on affective polarization and other outcomes

q2.value: Magdalena Wojcieszak, Andreu Casas, Ericka Menchen-Trevino, Miriam Boon

q3.value:
[See the document EXPO_No_News_Experiment-preregistration.pdf, submitted under the Design Plan setion, for a well-formatted and completed version of the pre-registration]

Many scholars accept that democracies function best when citizens are up-to-date on political events and knowledgeable about the issues of the day (e.g., Delli Carpini Keeter, 1996). Citizens are thus expected to attend to political information and news exposure has been seen as normatively beneficial (as reflected, for instance, in social desirability bias leading to overreporting of news consumption in survey self-reports; Prior, 2009). Yet, the current media environment allows for unprecedented levels of exposure to like-minded news sources and political content, which presents various challenges. A narrow information diet may be in part to blame for reinforcing people’s political attitudes (e.g., Levendusky, 2013) and for growing affective polarization or the animosity between people who identify with opposing political parties (e.g., Garrett et al., 2014). In this project, we problematize the notion of news exposure being necessarily democratically desirable and, in so doing, we offer a novel take on the problem of polarization. We propose that decreasing people’s news exposure in general - even after accounting for their prior levels of news exposure and for the potential simultaneous decreases in like-minded exposure - will attenuate both attitude and affective polarization. We also suspect that it will improve people’s perceptions of the political system, enhancing support for compromise and also lowering perceived levels of polarization and of attribution to negative intentions to the outparty. In addition to these positive effects, we examine two democratically negative consequences of ”news vacation,” i.e., decreased political knowledge and participatory intentions, and also explore its effects on an under-studied factor, namely individual general well-being.

To test these effects, we incentivize ($10) participants in our ongoing panel (N = 1,025) to go on a “news vacation” (i.e., to stop following the news for a one-week period). In the analyses, we aim to disentangle the effects of decreasing news exposure in general from the effects of decreasing like-minded exposure, while also testing whether these effects depend on people’s prior levels of news consumption and the intensity of their political predispositions.

[ A ] ATTITUDE POLARIZATION
---------------------
---------------------


Question 1: Do people hold weaker and less personally important policy attitudes after
decreasing news consumption?
We will explore potential changes for two outcomes related to attitude polarization: the strength of respondents attitudes on a set of issues (such as immigration, climate change,and the economy) and how important these issues are to them. We will explore general as well as different types of heterogeneous effects.

• Attitude Strength
-------------------
after decreasing news consumption, we expect people to be less aware of (and/or likely to forget about) the existence of extreme opposing views, and so to be less likely to adopt a defensive strategy when it comes to their policy posi- tions (Abelson 1986). Also, “news vacation” decreases people’s exposure to potentially polarizing party and elite cues, which are known to activate latent partisan biases in the minds of citizens, thereby enhancing the expression of support for various political values (Goren et al., 2012), exacerbating attitude strength (see Druckman et al., 2013), and leading voters to hold more consistent attitudes (Levendusky, 2009), including on contentious political topics (e.g., Hart & Nisbet, 2012; see also Nicholson, 2012). Those on news vacation should consequently hold weaker and less personally important issue attitudes and - a crucial innovation of this project - we predict this to be the case even after accounting for people’s levels of prior like-minded news browsing. In other words, decreasing news will exert effects above and beyond decreasing like-minded news.

In addition to this aggregate effect, we expect heterogeneous effects dependent on three interrelated factors. First, those with high levels of previous news consumption should be most strongly influenced by the treatment, in that the treatment will constitute the largest change to their typical news behavior. We examine both (a) self-reported and (b) online behavioral indicators of prior news consumption levels. Second, the treatment should have the strongest effects on those whose prior news diet is most ideologically like-minded, as like-minded exposure is known to strengthen individual political atti- tudes (e.g., Levendusky, 2013) and so decreasing news exposure should weaken them. Again, we study like-minded exposure as based on both (a) self-reports and (b) on- line behavioral traces. Third, the treatment effects should depend on the strength of individual political predispositions, such that we expect larger effects for those with stronger and more personally important pre-treatment issue attitudes, stronger par- tisanship, ideology, and party identity strength. The strong political identities and predispositions of those individuals will not be activated by external political cues and will become less accessible (see Knobloch-Westerwick & Meng, 2011). Because those with weak political predispositions have - by definition - less accessible priors, the treat- ment effect should be less pronounced.

Treatment
---------
H1: Respondents who did not follow the news for one week will have weaker issue attitudes, compared to those in the control group and to their pre-treatment attitude strength.

H1a: The weakening effect will hold when accounting for people’s prior levels of like-minded exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H1b: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H1c: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.

Treatment × Pre-treatment Attitude Strength
--------------------------------------------
H1d: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior attitude strength.

Treatment × (Party | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
--------------------------------------------------------
H1e,f,g: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of (party | ideology | party identity) strength.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption × Like-minded news consumption
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
H1h: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher piror levels of news exposure that furthermore is like-minded.



• Attitude Importance
---------------------
For the same reasons as above (i.e., decreased activation of one’s political identity, issue positions, and lower exposure to information about the discussed policies), we expect the same set of main and heterogeneous effects on post- test attitude importance.
Treatment
---------
H2: Respondents who did not follow the news for one week will view a set of political issues as less personally important, compared to respondents in the control group and to their pre-treatment issue importance measures.
H2a: The weakening effect will hold even after accounting for people’s prior levels of like-minded exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H2b: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of news exposure

Treatment × Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
--------------------------------------------------------
H2c: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.

Treatment × Pre-treatment Attitude Importance
---------------------------------------------        
H2d: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior attitude importance. 

Treatment × (Party | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
--------------------------------------------------------
H2e,f,g: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of (party | ideology | party identity) strength.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption × Like-minded news consumption
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
H2h The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher piror levels of news exposure that, moreover, is like-minded.


[ B ] AFFECTIVE POLARIZATION
----------------------------
----------------------------

Question 2: Do people’s levels of affective polarization decrease after not following news for
one week?

Affective polarization, or the extent to which people hold negative attitudes towards political out-groups, can be related to one’s partisan opponents (e.g., Democrats for a Republican), one’s ideological outgroup (e.g., conservatives for a liberal), and/or toward those who hold different views on various political issues. This project assesses all these (potentially dis- tinct) outgroups. We expect people’s levels of affective polarization to decrease after “news vacation,” during which they are not exposed to (a) salient political cues from the elites and the media, which are found to activate partisan identities and influence cognitions, attitudes, and behaviors (e.g., Druckman et al., 2013; Nicholson, 2012) and (b) media coverage that tends to highlight the existence and relevance of political conflict between Democrats and the Republicans (see Levendusky & Malhotra, 2016), factors that activate and exacerbate peo- ple’s dislike towards the political outgroup. Ultimately, affective polarization should decrease among the treated groups. We expect the effect to be heterogeneous, respondents with higher levels of prior news exposure, higher levels of like-minded news exposure, and with stronger party, ideology, and party identity should depolarize at a higher rate than their counterparts with lower levels of (like-minded) news exposure and with weaker political predispositions in the treatment group and than their counterparts with comparable levels of (like-minded) news consumption and of political predispositions in the control group.

Treatment
---------
H3: The levels of (party- | ideology- | issue-)based affective polarization will be lower for respondents who did not follow the news for one week, compared to respondents in the control group and to their pre-treatment levels of affective polarization.

H3a: The lowering effects will hold even after accounting for people’s prior levels of like-minded exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H3b: The lowering effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
--------------------------------------------------------
H3c: The lowering effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.

Treatment × (Partisan | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
-----------------------------------------------------------
H3d,e,f: The lowering effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of (party | ideology | party identity) strength.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption × Like-minded news consumption
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
H3h: The lowering effect will be stronger among those with higher piror levels of news exposure that, moreover, is like-minded.



[ C ] PERCEPTION OF THE POLITICAL SYSTEM

Question 3: Does people’s perception of the political system improve after not being exposed
to news for one week?

Literature suggests that a positive perception of the political system contributes to political stability and facilitates a well-functioning democracy (Marien and Hooghe 2001, Acemoglu et al. 2001, Agroskin et al. 2015). In this experiment we focus on the effects of our treatment on three systemic indicators: a) whether respondents believe that the out-party wants to harm the country (i.e., attribution of malevolence), b) whether politicians should be open to compromise, and c) perceived polarization. In line with affective polarization hypotheses, we expect “news vacation” to decrease the awareness of and familiarity with the presence of divergent views, conflicted groups, and divisive policies, therefore leading to more positive evaluations of the state and health of the political system (see Levendusky & Malhotra, 2016). As before, we expect the effects to be stronger among those with higher prior (like-mined) news exposure and with stronger party, ideology and party identity. Participants with lower (like-minded) news exposure and with weaker party and ideological attachments are likely to have lower prior attribution of malevolence, higher support for compromise across party lines, and be less aware of the salient political conflicts (perceived polarization). For those people, therefore, “news vacation” may have less pronounced effects compared to those who consume a lot of (like-minded) news and to strong partisans/ideologues.


• Attribution of Malevolence
----------------------------
The extent to which people believe that the other party wants to harm the country.

Treatment
---------
H4: Respondents who do not follow the news for one week will be less likely to perceive that the other party wants to harm the country, compared to respondents in the control group and to their prior levels of attribution of malevolence.

H4a: The lowering effect will hold when accounting for people’s prior levels of like- minded exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H4b: The lowering effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
--------------------------------------------------------
H4c: The lowering effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels like- minded news exposure. 

Treatment × (Partisan | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
-----------------------------------------------------------
H4d,e,f The lowering effects will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of (party | ideology | party identity) strength.


• Willingness to Compromise 
----------------------------
The extent to which people believe that politicians should be open to compromise. 

Treatment
---------
H5: Respondents who are not exposed to news for one week will be more likely to believe that politicians should be willing to compromise, relative to the control group and to their pre-test levels of support for compromise.

H5a: The positive effect will hold when accounting for people’s prior levels of like- minded exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H5b: The positive effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
--------------------------------------------------------
H5c: The positive effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like- minded news exposure.

Treatment × (Partisan | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
-----------------------------------------------------------
H5d,e,f: The positive effect will be stronger among those with higher levels of (party | ideology | party identity) strength.


• Perceived Polarization
------------------------
The extent to which people see polarization as prevalent. 

Treatment
---------
H6: Respondents who are not exposed to the news for one week will less likely to perceive political polarization as a prevalent phenomenon, compared to those in the control group and their pretest levels of perceived polarization.

H6a: The weakening effect will hold when accounting for people’s prior levels of like-minded exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of news consumption
--------------------------------------------
H6b: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment × Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
--------------------------------------------------------
H6c: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.

Treatment × (Partisan | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
-----------------------------------------------------------
H6d,e,f: The weakening effect will be stronger among those with higher levels of (party | ideology | party identity) strength.

[ D ] POLITICAL PARTICIPATION AND KNOWLEDGE
-------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------

Question 4: Does people’s political engagement (i.e., political participation and political knowledge) decrease after not being exposed to news?

Decades of research clearly show that attending to news enhances political knowledge (because people become aware of the important policies and facts of the day) (Delli Carpini & Keeter, 1996; see also Beam et al, 2017) and that it also motivates people to take part in the political process, partly because they become aware of the important issues and feel more efficacious (Putnam 2000, Norris 2000, Prior 2007). Therefore, those on a “news vacation” should have lower knowledge of the facts of the day and lower reported participatory intentions.

Treatment
---------
H7: Respondents who are not exposed to the news for a week will know less about recent political events than those in a control group.

H8: Respondents who are not exposed to the news for a week will have lower participatory intentions, relative to the respondents in a control group and to their pre-treatment participatory intentions.


[ E ] WELL BEING
----------------
----------------

Question 5: Does people’s well being improve after not being exposed to news?

A recent survey from the American Psychological Association found that“news consumption
has a downside.” More than half of Americans say the news causes them stress, and many re-
port feeling anxiety, fatigue or sleep loss as a result (Jan 31, 2018, see https://time.com/5125894/is- reading-news-bad-for-you/). Other research similarly suggests that watching daily news cor- relates with negative affect, especially when news is personally relevant (Hoog & Verboon, 2019) and that hard news consumption is associated with decline in mental well-being, likely because the news focus on negative stories, generating a sense of powerlessnes (Boukes & Vliegenthart, 2017). To our knowledge, overtime causal estimates are missing in the liter- ature. We fill this gap and expect that the well-being of respondents will improve after a “news vacation.” In line with the expectations presented above, we particularly expect this to be the case for those with high levels of prior news consumption.

Treatment
---------
H9a: Not being exposed to news for a week will improve respondents’ well being relative to the well being of the respondents in a control group.

Treatment × (Partisan | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
-----------------------------------------------------------
H9b,c,d: Not being exposed to news for a week have the strongest effect on improved well being for those respondents with higher (party | ideology | party identity).

Question 4: Does people’s political engagement (i.e., political participation and political knowledge) decrease after not being exposed to news?

Decades of research clearly show that attending to news enhances political knowledge (because people become aware of the important policies and facts of the day) (Delli Carpini & Keeter, 1996; see also Beam et al, 2017) and that it also motivates people to take part in the political process, partly because they become aware of the important issues and feel more efficacious (Putnam 2000, Norris 2000, Prior 2007). Therefore, those on a “news vacation” should have lower knowledge of the facts of the day and lower reported participatory intentions.

Treatment
---------
H7: Respondents who are not exposed to the news for a week will know less about recent political events than those in a control group.

H8: Respondents who are not exposed to the news for a week will have lower participatory intentions, relative to the respondents in a control group and to their pre-treatment participatory intentions.


[ E ] WELL BEING
----------------
----------------

Question 5: Does people’s well being improve after not being exposed to news?

A recent survey from the American Psychological Association found that“news consumption
has a downside.” More than half of Americans say the news causes them stress, and many re-
port feeling anxiety, fatigue or sleep loss as a result (Jan 31, 2018, see https://time.com/5125894/is- reading-news-bad-for-you/). Other research similarly suggests that watching daily news cor- relates with negative affect, especially when news is personally relevant (Hoog & Verboon, 2019) and that hard news consumption is associated with decline in mental well-being, likely because the news focus on negative stories, generating a sense of powerlessnes (Boukes & Vliegenthart, 2017). To our knowledge, overtime causal estimates are missing in the liter- ature. We fill this gap and expect that the well-being of respondents will improve after a “news vacation.” In line with the expectations presented above, we particularly expect this to be the case for those with high levels of prior news consumption.

Treatment
---------
H9a: Not being exposed to news for a week will improve respondents’ well being relative to the well being of the respondents in a control group.

Treatment × (Partisan | Ideology | Party Identity) Strength
-----------------------------------------------------------
H9b,c,d: Not being exposed to news for a week have the strongest effect on improved well being for those respondents with higher (party | ideology | party identity).

question10b.value:
Once participants provide informed consent, they will respond to demographic questions on age, gender, ethnicity, and political orientation. Next, participants will complete three uncertainty scales adapted from Rast, Gaffney, Hogg, & Crisp, 2012, measuring social uncertainty, financial uncertainty, and existential uncertainty. The order of these three scales will be randomized. Next, they will complete a general self-uncertainty scale. 

Following this, participants will be told that the next set of questions will ask for their opinions on political leadership in the UK (Study 1) or Justin Trudeau, the Prime Minster of Canada (Study 2). Participants will first complete the measure of autocratic leadership. Next, participants will respond to a series of scales designed to assess their evaluation of the leader. These scales measure leader prototypicality, leader support, leader trust, and perceived leader effectiveness. Next, will participants complete the measure of wish for a strong leader.

Participants will then be told that the next set of questions will ask for their opinion on possible policies related to COVID-19. In this section, participants will complete the measures of support for quarantine and support for restriction of civil liberties.

Finally, participants will be told that the next section will ask for their opinions on various types of political systems. Participants will complete the measures of support for nondemocratic governance, support for democracy, nationalism, and authoritarian submission. At the end of the study, participants will be thanked for their time, fully debriefed, and redirected to receive their compensation.

question4b.value: Participants will be recruited via Prolific (Study 1) or CloudResearch (Study 2). In Study 1, participants will be restricted to residents of the United Kingdom. In Study 2, participants will be restricted to residents of Canada. No other pre-selection rules will be applied.

question5b.value: Participants will be told that they are invited to take part in a research study on political views during the COVID-19 pandemic, and that the purpose of the study is to examine how people feel about political leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic. Participants will complete the entire study online via Qualtrics.

question6b.value: We will recruit 500 participants for each study (1,000 total). This sample size was determined based on a priori statistical power analyses and gives us confidence in drawing trustworthy conclusions from the data.

question7b.value: Data collection will be terminated once 500 participants have completed each study.

question8b.value: Participants will be excluded from final data analysis if they fail to finish the study in its entirety or if they fail one or more of the attention checks.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: Autocratic leadership style will be negatively associated with leader evaluation, such that higher levels of autocratic leadership will predict less favorable leader evaluation.

Hypothesis 2: Autocratic leadership style and uncertainty will interact to predict leader evaluation, such that less uncertain participants will evaluate their leader more favorably when they perceive the leader as non-autocratic, whereas more uncertain participants will evaluate their leader more favorably when the leader is perceived to be autocratic.

Hypothesis 3: The interaction between autocratic leadership style and uncertainty on leader evaluation will be mediated by leader prototypicality, such that high uncertainty will be associated with a stronger perception that an autocratic leader is prototypical.  

Hypothesis 4: Uncertainty will be positively associated with wish for a strong leader.

Hypothesis 5: Uncertainty will be positively associated with willingness to restrict civil liberties.

Hypothesis 6: Uncertainty will be negatively associated with support for democracy and positively associated with support for nondemocratic governance.

Hypothesis 7: Uncertainty will be positively association with nationalism.

Hypothesis 8: Uncertainty will be positively association with authoritarian submission.

attributes.title: Increasing the relative availability of healthier vs. less healthy food: Can impact be explained in terms of prior preferences?
attributes.description: Increasing the availability of healthier or more plant-based foods increases their selection. One possible mechanism that might underlie these effects is individuals’ prior preferences, whereby selections reflect individuals’ most-preferred option from the available range. The first exploration – to our knowledge – of the role of prior preferences as a possible mechanism underlying the effects of manipulating the relative availability of healthier and less healthy options suggested that a large majority of selections reflect the most-preferred option. However, only small differences were observed in preferences by option healthiness in this initial study.  These pilot and extension studies aim to explore this further.

q1.value: Rachel Pechey, Gareth J Hollands, Theresa Marteau

q2.value:
Pilot
1.	Vegetarian options are less likely to be selected than comparable meat-based options (directional hypothesis)

Extension
1.	Reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options increases the likelihood of participants’ most-preferred option being a healthier option (directional hypothesis)
a.	Reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options increases the likelihood of participants’ most-preferred option being a healthier option to a greater extent for those with higher education (vs. lower education) (directional hypothesis)
2.	Participants’ most-preferred option within the offered range of products will often, but not always, correspond to the option that participants select (non-directional hypothesis)
i.	Participants’ most-preferred option within the offered range of products is more likely to correspond to the option that participants select when the option selected is less-healthy (vs. healthier) (directional hypothesis)

question.value:
Pilot: Between-subjects design, with 2 groups (vegetarian vs. meat-based)
Extension: Within-subjects design, with 2 groups (2 availability conditions)

q7.value:
Pilot: Participants will be randomised to either see vegetarian healthier meal options or meat-based healthier meal options.

Extension: Participants will be randomised as to the order in which they complete each trial. The items assigned to the array will be randomly selected from the pool of available healthier vs. less-healthy options. The position of items in each array will also be randomised.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be a sample of 540 UK adults for the pilot and 1080 adults for the extension study, recruited from an online panel run by a market research agency. The samples will have quotas set to ensure representative sample by age and gender, and equal numbers by socioeconomic status (based on highest educational qualification). 

Inclusion criteria are that participants must be currently residing in the UK, and be at least 18 years old. 

Exclusion criteria are that participants must not have any dietary restrictions (e.g. vegetarians), to ensure that participants feel they have a choice between the options offered. 

In addition, participants must correctly answer quality control questions as part of the studies to ensure that they are paying attention to the questions. Anyone answering incorrectly will be screened out and will not be counted towards the study quotas.

Participants are paid the equivalent to UK minimum wage for their time spent completing the survey.

q11.value: Participants will be a sample of 540 UK adults for the pilot and 1080 UK adults for the extension study.

q12.value:
Pilot:
Based on a t-test to test for a difference in selections of comparable vegetarian and meat-based meals, to find an effect size equivalent to the difference in ranks between healthier and less healthy main meals in Study 1 (d=0.28), with alpha=0.05, and power of 0.9, the sample size required was calculated using G*Power 3.1.9.2 to be 270 per group, so 540 in total.

Extension:
The sample size was determined using a simulation-based approach to predicting power for a multilevel logistic regression (Olvera Astivia, Gadermann, & Guhn, 2019). Each simulation was based on 100 replications, using a model with: 
-	two level 1 units (representing the two selections made by each participant)
-	one level 1 binary covariate, with equal numbers of participants: availability condition [d=0.38, equivalent to the smallest effect of availability found in previous online studies]
-	intercept variance of 0.64 and beta of 1.4 [from previous study]
Simulations suggested that a sample of 1080 individuals would achieve a power of 0.92 for the estimated effect of availability on whether or not participants’ most-preferred option was healthier.

question.value:
Pilot:
Main meal type: This will be manipulated by presenting participants with either healthier meat-based main meal options or equivalent vegetarian options

Extension:
Availability: This will be manipulated by asking participants to select an item from an array of snack foods that they would most like to eat right now. This array will differ between participants depending on their assignment of one of two conditions: 1 healthier & 3 less healthy (increased less healthy); 3 healthier & 1 less healthy (increased healthier).

Pilot
Outcome measure:
The ranking of each item relative to other study items in terms of individual preferences

Extension
Outcome measure:
Choice of food (healthier or less healthy) from array offered

Predictors (both studies):
Socioeconomic status: Two indicators: (1) highest educational qualification, (2) total annual household income
Demographics: Gender, age, hunger (7-pt rating scale from Very hungry – Very full), usual meat consumption (6 options: Less than once a week; 1-3 times a week; 4-6 times a week; Once a day; Twice a day; More than twice a day).

Additional predictor for extension study:
Baseline relative preferences: The ranking of each item relative to other study items in terms of individual preferences

Pilot ranking/Baseline relative preferences: Participants will be presented with pictures of two food options, and asked to choose which they would prefer to eat right now. They will complete this task for every possible item pair. The selected item receives a score of 1 for that trial. Scores are summed across all trials for each item. The item with the lowest score is considered to be lowest ranked in terms of order of preference, and so on. This gives us their relative preference rankings across each set of food options that they will choose from in each availability condition. For ties in relative rankings both tied items’ rankings will be recorded as 1.5, 2.5 or 3.5 (i.e. tied for first, second or third place respectively).

Pilot:
1. How often is each option selected, after being paired against each other option?
Descriptive table of the mean ranking score for each of the options. The most-preferred (lowest ranking score) four less-healthy options, and least-preferred (highest ranking score) four healthier options would be selected for the extension study.

2. Are vegetarian options less likely to be selected than comparable meat-based options?
Multiple regression predicting the ranking score of healthier options, based on whether or not these options were meat-based. The reference group will be the healthier meat-based options. Age, gender, education and hunger would be included as covariates.

Extension study:
Manipulation check: Does reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options alter healthiness of participants’ selected options?
Mixed effects logistic regression, conducted at the participant-level, comparing whether ranges of options of (a) one healthier, three less healthy options or (b) three healthier, one less healthy options alter the healthiness of participants’ selected options, with random effects for participant 
Covariates: Age, gender, hunger

Background check: Are less healthy options preferred over healthier options?
Comparing the mean ranking of healthier options to the mean ranking of less-healthy options, analysed using paired t-tests

Main analyses:
To explore the proposed pathway:
(A) Increasing the availability of healthier items and/or decreasing the availability of less healthy items   -> (B) a healthier item is more likely to be the most-preferred option out of the offered range -> (C) a healthier item is more likely to be selected from the offered range

Question 1: Proposed pathway, (A)-(B): 
i.	Does reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options alter the healthiness of participants’ most-preferred options?
Mixed effects logistic regression, conducted at the participant-level, comparing whether offering ranges of options containing (a) one healthier, three less healthy options vs. (b) three healthier, one less healthy options, alter the likelihood that participants’ most-preferred option is a healthier option, with random effects for participant
Covariates: Age, gender, hunger

ii.	Does reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options alter the mean ranking of the most-preferred (a) healthier and (b) less-healthy items in the range?
Comparing (a) the mean ranking of the most-preferred healthier option in the predominantly less-healthy range to the mean ranking of the most-preferred healthier option in the predominantly healthier range and (b) the mean ranking of the most-preferred less-healthy option in the predominantly less-healthy range to the mean ranking of the most-preferred less-healthy option in the predominantly healthier range. Analysed using paired t-tests

Question 2: Proposed pathway, (B)-(C): 
i.	To what extent does product selection reflect participants’ most-preferred option within the offered range of products?
Descriptive statistics: the proportion of time options that were ranked 1st, 2nd, 3rd or 4th within the offered range were selected, by availability condition, as well as overall.

ii.	Does this vary by the healthiness of the product?
Mixed effects logistic regression, conducted at the participant-level, examining whether a dummy variable indicating the healthiness of participants’ most-preferred option from ranges of options of (a) one healthier, three less healthy options or (b) three healthier, one less healthy options alters the likelihood that participants select their most-preferred option, with random effects for participant
Covariates: Age, gender, hunger

Socioeconomic analysis:	
Socioeconomic patterning:

Pilot: Participants will be randomised to either see vegetarian healthier meal options or meat-based healthier meal options.

Extension: Participants will be randomised as to the order in which they complete each trial. The items assigned to the array will be randomly selected from the pool of available healthier vs. less-healthy options. The position of items in each array will also be randomised.

registration_responses.q11: Participants will be a sample of 540 UK adults for the pilot and 1080 UK adults for the extension study.
registration_responses.q12:
Pilot:
Based on a t-test to test for a difference in selections of comparable vegetarian and meat-based meals, to find an effect size equivalent to the difference in ranks between healthier and less healthy main meals in Study 1 (d=0.28), with alpha=0.05, and power of 0.9, the sample size required was calculated using G*Power 3.1.9.2 to be 270 per group, so 540 in total.

Extension:
The sample size was determined using a simulation-based approach to predicting power for a multilevel logistic regression (Olvera Astivia, Gadermann, & Guhn, 2019). Each simulation was based on 100 replications, using a model with: 
-	two level 1 units (representing the two selections made by each participant)
-	one level 1 binary covariate, with equal numbers of participants: availability condition [d=0.38, equivalent to the smallest effect of availability found in previous online studies]
-	intercept variance of 0.64 and beta of 1.4 [from previous study]
Simulations suggested that a sample of 1080 individuals would achieve a power of 0.92 for the estimated effect of availability on whether or not participants’ most-preferred option was healthier.

registration_responses.q6.question:
Pilot: Between-subjects design, with 2 groups (vegetarian vs. meat-based)
Extension: Within-subjects design, with 2 groups (2 availability conditions)
registration_responses.q10.question:
Participants will be a sample of 540 UK adults for the pilot and 1080 adults for the extension study, recruited from an online panel run by a market research agency. The samples will have quotas set to ensure representative sample by age and gender, and equal numbers by socioeconomic status (based on highest educational qualification). 

Inclusion criteria are that participants must be currently residing in the UK, and be at least 18 years old. 

Exclusion criteria are that participants must not have any dietary restrictions (e.g. vegetarians), to ensure that participants feel they have a choice between the options offered. 

In addition, participants must correctly answer quality control questions as part of the studies to ensure that they are paying attention to the questions. Anyone answering incorrectly will be screened out and will not be counted towards the study quotas.

Participants are paid the equivalent to UK minimum wage for their time spent completing the survey.
registration_responses.q14.question:
Pilot:
Main meal type: This will be manipulated by presenting participants with either healthier meat-based main meal options or equivalent vegetarian options

Extension:
Availability: This will be manipulated by asking participants to select an item from an array of snack foods that they would most like to eat right now. This array will differ between participants depending on their assignment of one of two conditions: 1 healthier & 3 less healthy (increased less healthy); 3 healthier & 1 less healthy (increased healthier).
registration_responses.q15.question:
Pilot
Outcome measure:
The ranking of each item relative to other study items in terms of individual preferences

Extension
Outcome measure:
Choice of food (healthier or less healthy) from array offered

Predictors (both studies):
Socioeconomic status: Two indicators: (1) highest educational qualification, (2) total annual household income
Demographics: Gender, age, hunger (7-pt rating scale from Very hungry – Very full), usual meat consumption (6 options: Less than once a week; 1-3 times a week; 4-6 times a week; Once a day; Twice a day; More than twice a day).

Additional predictor for extension study:
Baseline relative preferences: The ranking of each item relative to other study items in terms of individual preferences
registration_responses.q16.question: Pilot ranking/Baseline relative preferences: Participants will be presented with pictures of two food options, and asked to choose which they would prefer to eat right now. They will complete this task for every possible item pair. The selected item receives a score of 1 for that trial. Scores are summed across all trials for each item. The item with the lowest score is considered to be lowest ranked in terms of order of preference, and so on. This gives us their relative preference rankings across each set of food options that they will choose from in each availability condition. For ties in relative rankings both tied items’ rankings will be recorded as 1.5, 2.5 or 3.5 (i.e. tied for first, second or third place respectively).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Pilot:
1. How often is each option selected, after being paired against each other option?
Descriptive table of the mean ranking score for each of the options. The most-preferred (lowest ranking score) four less-healthy options, and least-preferred (highest ranking score) four healthier options would be selected for the extension study.

2. Are vegetarian options less likely to be selected than comparable meat-based options?
Multiple regression predicting the ranking score of healthier options, based on whether or not these options were meat-based. The reference group will be the healthier meat-based options. Age, gender, education and hunger would be included as covariates.

Extension study:
Manipulation check: Does reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options alter healthiness of participants’ selected options?
Mixed effects logistic regression, conducted at the participant-level, comparing whether ranges of options of (a) one healthier, three less healthy options or (b) three healthier, one less healthy options alter the healthiness of participants’ selected options, with random effects for participant 
Covariates: Age, gender, hunger

Background check: Are less healthy options preferred over healthier options?
Comparing the mean ranking of healthier options to the mean ranking of less-healthy options, analysed using paired t-tests

Main analyses:
To explore the proposed pathway:
(A) Increasing the availability of healthier items and/or decreasing the availability of less healthy items   -> (B) a healthier item is more likely to be the most-preferred option out of the offered range -> (C) a healthier item is more likely to be selected from the offered range

Question 1: Proposed pathway, (A)-(B): 
i.	Does reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options alter the healthiness of participants’ most-preferred options?
Mixed effects logistic regression, conducted at the participant-level, comparing whether offering ranges of options containing (a) one healthier, three less healthy options vs. (b) three healthier, one less healthy options, alter the likelihood that participants’ most-preferred option is a healthier option, with random effects for participant
Covariates: Age, gender, hunger

ii.	Does reducing less healthy options and increasing healthier options alter the mean ranking of the most-preferred (a) healthier and (b) less-healthy items in the range?
Comparing (a) the mean ranking of the most-preferred healthier option in the predominantly less-healthy range to the mean ranking of the most-preferred healthier option in the predominantly healthier range and (b) the mean ranking of the most-preferred less-healthy option in the predominantly less-healthy range to the mean ranking of the most-preferred less-healthy option in the predominantly healthier range. Analysed using paired t-tests

Question 2: Proposed pathway, (B)-(C): 
i.	To what extent does product selection reflect participants’ most-preferred option within the offered range of products?
Descriptive statistics: the proportion of time options that were ranked 1st, 2nd, 3rd or 4th within the offered range were selected, by availability condition, as well as overall.

ii.	Does this vary by the healthiness of the product?
Mixed effects logistic regression, conducted at the participant-level, examining whether a dummy variable indicating the healthiness of participants’ most-preferred option from ranges of options of (a) one healthier, three less healthy options or (b) three healthier, one less healthy options alters the likelihood that participants select their most-preferred option, with random effects for participant
Covariates: Age, gender, hunger

Socioeconomic analysis:	
Socioeconomic patterning: 
i.	Is there a difference in response to the availability manipulation by education?	
Analysis as outlined for the manipulation check above, including interactions between availability condition and education level  

If patterning observed in (i), we will explore mechanisms:
ii.	Do any effects observed in the main analyses vary depending on socioeconomic status?
Analyses as for Question 1 and Question 2 above, including a variable for education.

attributes.title: Examining the Influence of Published Failed Replications on Original Article Citation Habits
attributes.description: In this project, we are examining the influence of published failed replications on original article citation habits in social psychology. We are curious to see whether a) the average number of citations per year to original articles after publication of the failed replication is different than the average number of citations per year prior to the publication of the failed replication, and b) there is a difference in the number of citations to the replication article and the original article post publication of the replication article. This project will also keep in mind a) the valence of the framing of the original article, and b) the tendency for some failed replications to be published as standalone papers while others are one of many individual failed replications taht are reported as part of a large-scale replication study (e.g., Open Science Collaboration, 2015).

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Examining citations of original articles in social psychology following replication attempts.

sample.value: We will continuously enter as many relevant original-replication pairings as possible.

analyses.value:
Analyses will consist of independent samples t-tests to compare the citations described above. 

Average number of citations to original before vs. after replication publication (three versions: all citations, positive citations, negative citations)

Number of citations to original vs replication paper (post-publication of replication) (three versions: all citations, positive citations, negative citations)

outliers.value: We will only include failed replication attempts.

dependent.value: The key variables are citation counts for original and replication papers, and the years these papers were published. This information will be determined by GoogleScholar. The pool of original and replication papers is drawn from two primary sources: a) independent review of the literature for relevant papers by trained undergraduates, and b) original/replication papers cited in Reinero et al. (2020), who compiled a list of over 190 replication attempts. In addition, two trained students will review each article to determine whether the citation to an original paper after publication of a failed replication attempt is critical or not of the original findings.

study_type_other.value: The data collection is continuous for this project as more and more relevant data are identified. We plan to conduct our main analyses with a large data set of studies (roughly 200), but will add more as they are identified, with the goal of thoroughness.

attributes.title: Comparative efficacy and acceptability of individual cognitive behavior therapy and group cognitive behavior therapy for anxiety disorder in children and adolescents--A Meta analysis
attributes.description: Anxiety disorder in youth is a common mental health disorders with an estimate of lifetime prevalence from 15% to 20%, and typically have their onset in childhood or early adolescence. Untreated anxiety disorder in children and adolescents is related to poor functions and bring significant risks for psychopathology and dysfunction in later life. Individual cognitive behavior therapy (ICBT) and group cognitive behavior therapy (GCBT) are commonly used for anxiety disorder in children and adolescents. To date, emerging clinical trials comparing the efficacy of ICBT and GCBT have been conducted, but the results are controversial. Thus, we designed a meta-analysis to determine the efficacy and acceptability of individual cognitive behavior therapy and group cognitive behavior therapy for anxiety disorder in children and

summary.value:
Background: Anxiety disorder is the most prevalent mental disorder in children and adolescents. Individual cognitive behavior therapy (ICBT) and group cognitive behavior therapy (GCBT) are commonly used in treating anxiety disorders in children and adolescents. However, it remains unclear which one is more effective and acceptable for treating children and adolescents with anxiety disorder.
Method: Eight electronic databases (PubMed, Embase, Cochrane, Web of Science, CINAHL, PsycINFO, ProQuest and LILACS) were searched from inception to October 2019. We included randomized controlled trials comparing ICBT with GCBT for anxiety disorder in children and adolescents (aged ≤ 18 years). Primary outcomes were the efficacy (mean change in anxiety symptom scores at post-treatment) and acceptability (all-cause discontinuation). Secondary outcomes were remission and mean change in anxiety symptom scores at follow-up.
Result: Nine studies with 871 participants were selected in the meta-analysis. The pooled analyses indicated no significant difference between ICBT and GCBT for reducing the symptoms of anxiety at posttreatment (standardized mean difference [SMD], -0.10; 95% confidence interval [CI], -0.26 to 0.06, p = 0.22), follow-up (SMD, -0.44; 95% CI, -1.08 to 0.19, p = 0.17) and remission (odds ratio [OR], 1.15; 95% CI, 0.79 to 1.66, p = 0.47). No statistically significant difference for acceptability was found between the two therapy types (OR, 1.30; 95% CI, 0.61 to 2.77, p = 0.50). ICBT was superior to control group in anxiety symptoms reduction (SMD = -0.30, p = 0.009) and remission (OR = 4.00, p = 0.0002), and GCBT was superior to control group in remission (OR = 7.17, p < 0.0001). Subgroup analysis showed that ICBT was significantly more effective than GCBT in adolescents at post-treatment, but no significant in children.
Conclusion: ICBT and GCBT are effective in treating anxiety disorder in children and adolescents with no differences in efficacy and acceptability. In adolescents, ICBT seems to be more beneficial than GCBT. Further well-designed clinical studies should be performed to confirm these findings.

Key Words: Anxiety disorder, individual cognitive behavior therapy, group cognitive behavior therapy, child, adolescent, meta-analysis

attributes.title: Investigating the moderating effects of Psychopathy on the relationship between Perceived Socioeconomic Status and Perceived Stress Reactivity
attributes.description: The purpose of this project is to examine the moderating effects that psychopathy may have on the relationship between  perceived socioeconomic status and perceived reactivity to stressors encountered in day-to-day life.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Investigating the moderating effects of Psychopathy on the relationship between Perceived Socioeconomic Status and Perceived Stress Reactivity.
The purpose of this project is to examine the moderating effects that psychopathy may have on the relationship between  perceived socioeconomic status and perceived reactivity to stressors encountered in day-to-day life.

sample.value: For the proposed analyses, a sample size of 119 participants will be sufficient to detect a medium effect size (f = 0.15), with 0.95 power at an alpha level of 0.05.  The investigation will therefore aim for 130 participants to allow for any drop-outs or missing data throughout the surveys.

analyses.value:
To analyse the data; a linear regression will be conducted to explore the relationship between socioeconomic status and self-reported stress reactivity. Centred scores for perceived SES and psychopathy, as well as the interaction between these terms will be entered in a single step. Separate analyses will be run for the total score on the PSRS as well as for each of the subscales of this instrument.   
To futher probe any significant moderating effects of psychopathy on the relationship between SES and perceived stress, simple slopes moderation analyses will be conducted.

outliers.value: In order to reduce any ethical implications, the exclusion criteria are that participants must be over 18 years of age and must not have any existing mental health diagnoses.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable being measured in this investigation is perceived stress reactivity, which will be measured using The Perceived Stress Reactivity Scale (PSRS; Schlotz et al, 2011).
The moderator variable being measured is Psychopathy, using the Levenson’s Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (LSRP; Levenson et al, 1995), where a psychopathy score will be generated for each participant.

conditions.value:
The study will be an online questionnaire implementing a quantitative self-report methodology.
Data will be collected using self-report questionnaires provided to the participant via a Qualtrics link. 
Socioeconomic Status will be investigated, which will be measured using the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler et al, 2000).
Psychopathy will also be investigated as a moderator, using the Levenson’s Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (LSRP; Levenson et al, 1995).
Perceived Stress will also be measured in the online survey, using 'The Perceived Stress Reactivity Scale' (PSRS; Schlotz et al, 2011) to calculate a stress reactivity score for each participant, as well as a score for each subscale.

hypothesis.value:
Socioeconomic status (SES) is a common predictor of a range of health and illness outcomes, for example low SES is associated with a higher prevalence of mental health problems, distress and other health impairing behaviours (Baum et al, 2006); all of which, are related to increased levels of stress. Research has frequently found that low SES is related to increased levels of stress hormones. For example, lower SES; determined by levels of education and income, was associated with increased levels of adrenaline and cortisol (Cohen et al, 2006).  Another study found that family SES was inversely related to cortisol levels, which lead to the conclusion that SES may have links to cardiovascular disease via cortisol reactivity to stress (Kapuko et al, 2002). There is ample evidence supporting the relationship between SES and stress, however, further investigation is vital to understand the factors which may buffer this relationship.
The current investigation will measure perceived socioeconomic status using the The MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler et al, 2000). 
Individual differences such as personality can predict a person’s reaction to stress. A relatively understudied personality trait, in relation to stress reactivity, is psychopathic personality. The relatively small number of studies which have investigated this trait, which is characterised by callousness and a lack of remorse in relation to stress have found that it is associated with blunted stress reactivity. Participants classed as high psychopathy among a sample of 48 incarcerated males had the lowest scores on Stanford Acute Stress reactivity questionnaire (Pham 2012). In terms of physiological reactions, urine, adrenaline and noradrenaline were measured in 24 male prisoners 2 weeks, 1 week and directly before their trial (Lidberg et al 1978). High psychopathy was linked to no increase in adrenaline or noradrenaline immediately before the trial, which is seemingly the most stressful timepoint, again supporting the notion of blunted stress reactivity in individuals high on psychopathy. 
However, a large majority of research into psychopathy is conducted using the incarcerated population when investigating the effects of psychopathic traits and stress, meaning we have a lack of knowledge about how psychopathic traits, among the non-incarcerated population, may be advantageous or detrimental in everyday life. Therefore, in the current study, we will administer a measure of psychopathic traits to members of the general population and measure their subjective stress response using the Perceived Stress Reactivity Scale (PSRS; Schlotz et al, 2011).
There is research suggesting that Socioeconomic Status (SES) may be associated with psychopathic traits. For example, increased callous-unemotional and narcissistic tendencies was found in youths with low SES (Sadeh et al, 2010), as well as risky decision-making being associated with psychopathic tendencies in children raised in benign home environments (Guo et al, 2009). However, no research has explored how psychopathy may moderate the relationship between SES and stress reactivity. 
Predicated by existing literature, the current study will study levels of psychopathy in the general population, exploring how this may moderate the relationship between socioeconomic status and a person’s perceived stress reactivity. 
The current investigation hypothesises that individuals with low SES will report greater levels of perceived stress reactivity. However, predicted by existing literature reporting blunted stress response in those exhibiting psychopathic traits, it is hypothesised that for individuals reporting high levels of psychopathy, the psychopathic traits will buffer against the adverse effects that low SES typically has on stress, thereby reducing the adverse effects of low SES on perceived stress reactivity.

The current investigation will measure perceived socioeconomic status using the The MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler et al, 2000). 
Individual differences such as personality can predict a person’s reaction to stress. A relatively understudied personality trait, in relation to stress reactivity, is psychopathic personality. The relatively small number of studies which have investigated this trait, which is characterised by callousness and a lack of remorse in relation to stress have found that it is associated with blunted stress reactivity. Participants classed as high psychopathy among a sample of 48 incarcerated males had the lowest scores on Stanford Acute Stress reactivity questionnaire (Pham 2012). In terms of physiological reactions, urine, adrenaline and noradrenaline were measured in 24 male prisoners 2 weeks, 1 week and directly before their trial (Lidberg et al 1978). High psychopathy was linked to no increase in adrenaline or noradrenaline immediately before the trial, which is seemingly the most stressful timepoint, again supporting the notion of blunted stress reactivity in individuals high on psychopathy. 
However, a large majority of research into psychopathy is conducted using the incarcerated population when investigating the effects of psychopathic traits and stress, meaning we have a lack of knowledge about how psychopathic traits, among the non-incarcerated population, may be advantageous or detrimental in everyday life. Therefore, in the current study, we will administer a measure of psychopathic traits to members of the general population and measure their subjective stress response using the Perceived Stress Reactivity Scale (PSRS; Schlotz et al, 2011).
There is research suggesting that Socioeconomic Status (SES) may be associated with psychopathic traits. For example, increased callous-unemotional and narcissistic tendencies was found in youths with low SES (Sadeh et al, 2010), as well as risky decision-making being associated with psychopathic tendencies in children raised in benign home environments (Guo et al, 2009). However, no research has explored how psychopathy may moderate the relationship between SES and stress reactivity. 
Predicated by existing literature, the current study will study levels of psychopathy in the general population, exploring how this may moderate the relationship between socioeconomic status and a person’s perceived stress reactivity. 
The current investigation hypothesises that individuals with low SES will report greater levels of perceived stress reactivity. However, predicted by existing literature reporting blunted stress response in those exhibiting psychopathic traits, it is hypothesised that for individuals reporting high levels of psychopathy, the psychopathic traits will buffer against the adverse effects that low SES typically has on stress, thereby reducing the adverse effects of low SES on perceived stress reactivity.

attributes.title: Electoral legitimacy and popular vote margins
attributes.description: Democracy depends on the shared legitimacy of the process that decides who holds power, including, critically, the consent of the losers. If the public does not believe that elected officials were chosen via a fair process, their trust in the government and confidence in the democratic system could erode dangerously. It is therefore critical to determine the factors that affect the public's perceptions of electoral fairness and legitimacy. Electoral victories by candidates who fail to win a popular vote plurality may present a challenge to perceptions of legitimacy, especially as the popular vote winner's margin increases. These decreases in perceptions of legitimacy for winning candidates who lose the popular vote may be greatest among supporters of the party of the losing candidate. We therefore experimentally test how popular vote margins and party labels affect people's perceptions of electoral legitimacy.

q2.value:
H1: We expect the perceived legitimacy of an election result to be lower if the EC winner loses the popular vote relative to when the EC vote and popular vote are won by the same candidate (H1A). When the EC winner and the popular vote winner are different, we expect the decline in perceived legitimacy will increase with the popular vote margin (H1B).

H2: We expect the perceived legitimacy of election results to be greater when a co-partisan wins the Electoral College.

H3: We expect the difference in perceived legitimacy between a co-partisan Electoral College winner and out-party Electoral College winner will be larger when the Electoral College winner loses the popular vote.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We study the effect of party (D/R), popular vote outcome (win/loss) and margin of the popular vote winner (one or three percentage points) on the perceived legitimacy of the Electoral College winner. Specifically, we conduct a between-subjects experiment in which respondents are asked to rate the legitimacy of an electoral outcome in which these three factors are randomly varied but the Electoral College outcome is held fixed.

q7.value: We will use simple randomization where the survey respondent is randomly assigned to oneof the eight conditions with equal probability

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: We are filing this pre-analysis plan prior to receiving complete study data from YouGov. We have 109 responses from a soft launch/pre-test that was collected to make sure survey programming was correct. We will not include the soft launch data in our analyses.

question.value: Participants will be recruited as part of YouGov's omnibus survey, which was fielded from approximately March 23--April 3, 2020. Participants are selected and weighted to be approximately representative of the US adult population.

We show survey respondents a vignette describing a electoral scenario in which a hypothetical president is elected:

"We are interested in how people judge the outcomes of presidential elections, which are decided in the United States by the Electoral College. In the question that follows, we will ask you about a possible outcomes of the 2020 presidential election. 

Imagine the {Democratic/Republican} candidate wins the Electoral College and the presidency in 2020 {and wins/but loses} the popular vote by {1/3} percentage points compared to the {Republican/Democratic} candidate."

Words bracketed in the first three sets of curly braces will be randomized (and the words in the fourth set of braces will be assigned to complement the opposite party assigned in the first set). We therefore have eight scenarios to test.

1. Independent variables
Our primary independent variables will be indicators for the popular vote margin conditions, for the partisanship of the winning candidate relative to the respondent, and (in some cases) for their interaction. 

The popular vote margin indicators will be specified as follows. We will include separate indicators for respondents who are randomly assigned to conditions in which the Electoral College winner wins the popular vote by 3 percentage points, loses the popular vote by 1 percentage point, or loses the popular vote by 3 percentage points. (The reference category will be respondents who were randomly assigned to a condition in which the Electoral College winner wins the popular vote by 1 percentage point.)

We will also include indicators of whether the candidate who wins the Electoral College was randomly assigned to be a co-partisan of the respondent or an opposition partisan. (We will count party leaners as party identifiers for this purpose as well.)

Finally, we will estimate models that include interactions between indicators for the popular vote margin and the partisanship of the Electoral College winner where appropriate.

To improve efficiency, all models will include measures of political interest, race, education, gender, and age from YouGov's profile data on its respondents as controls. Political interest will be measured by the following question: ``Some people seem to follow what’s going on in government and public affairs most of the time, whether there’s an election going on or not. Others aren't that interested. Would you say you follow what’s going on in government and public affairs.'' Responses are measured on a four-point Likert scale with a don't know option (which will be treated as missing). The most interested category will take the value of 4 and the least interested will take the value of 1. The race question will be measured with the following question: ``What racial or ethnic group best describes you?" and is answered in eight categories (White, Black, Hispanic/Latino, Asian, Native American, Middle Easter, Mixed Race, Other). We will include an indicator for respondents who do not identify as white that will take the value of 1 for nonwhite respondents and 0 for those who identify as white. Education levels are measured with the following question: ``What is the highest level of education you have completed?'' Respondents answer on a six-point scale from ``No high school degree'' to ``Post-graduate degree.'' We will include an indicator variable that takes a value of 1 if respondents have a four-year college degree and 0 if not. Finally, we will include indicators for respondents who identify as female to the question ``Are you male or female?" (1 if female, 0 if male) and indicators for ages 30--44, 45--59, and 60+ (age 18--29 will be the reference category). 

2. Dependent variables
We will ask a series of questions in randomized order designed to measure respondents' perceived sense of electoral legitimacy:

Would you consider the winning candidate to be the rightful winner of the election or not the rightful winner? (adapted from Gallup)
-Definitely the rightful winner
-Probably the rightful winner
-Probably not the rightful winner
-Definitely not the rightful winner


Would you view the winning candidate's presidency to be legitimate or not legitimate? (adapted from (Craig et. al 2006)
-Entirely legitimate
-Somewhat legitimate
-Not very legitimate
-Not legitimate at all

Do you think the winning candidate's victory was fair or not fair? (adapted from Gallup)
-Very fair
-Somewhat fair
-Not very fair
-Not at all fair

We will conduct a confirmatory factor analysis to verify that the three outcome measures load on a single dimension. If so, we will create a scaled outcome that reduces measurement error and therefore increases power (Broockman et.al 2017). It will be constructed as the mean of the three variables after transforming each variable so that the value that represents the greatest perceived legitimacy takes the value of 4 and the value that represents the least perceived legitimacy takes the value of 1. (If the variables do not load together, we will report the results separately for each measure.)

We will compute average treatment effects via OLS with robust standard errors. We describe the tests we will conduct for each hypothesis below using pseudo-code in Stata syntax (we may estimate these models using R instead; these are provided simply to formalize the models that we will estimate).

Variables:
-legitimacy = perceived legitimacy scale measure 
-lose3 = EC winner loses by 3 percentage points
-lose1 = EC winner loses by 1 percentage points
-win3 = EC winner wins by 3 percentage points
-copartisan = EC winner from party respondent identifies with or leans toward
-opposition = EC winner from opposition party to the one respondent identifies with or leans toward
-controls = the control variables listed above

H1:
reg legitimacy lose3 lose1 win3 copartisan opposition controls, robust 

H1a:
lincom lose1
lincom win3-lose1

H1b: 
lincom lose3
lincom lose3-lose1
lincom lose3-win3

H2:
lincom copartisan-opposition

H3: 
reg legitimacy lose3##copartisan lose3##opposition lose1##copartisan lose1##opposition
win3##copartisan win3##opposition controls, robust 

lincom lose3#copartisan-lose3#opposition
lincom lose1#copartisan-lose1#opposition

-We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models to test the hypotheses of interest, including marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from the models including interaction terms, treatment effects by subgroup, and differences in marginal effects between subgroups.
-In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible.
-We will compute and report summary statistics for our sample. We may also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention.
-The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity.
-Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit if appropriate.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for rejecting null hypotheses but will also report whether results are significant at the p<.01 and p<.005 levels.

q22.value: We plan to explore whether asymmetries are observed between Democrats and Republicans for H1--H3.
