attributes.title: Procedural justice and identity: Group work study
attributes.description: This study will examine authorities’ evaluations of their own decision-making processes as well as their evaluations of others’ decision-making in an experimental design. Additionally, the study will examine antecedents to providing procedural justice by examining the extent to which participants rely on subordinate voice to make decisions about sanctions (Folger et al., 1979). The synchronous online design will assign participants to the positions of authority and subordinate within a minimal-group paradigm (Gaertner et al., 1990; McDonald et al., 2011). The design will enable us to test the effects of position of authority on evaluations of decision-making procedures without any confounding societal or historical contexts, such as employer-employee or police-civilian relations. Additionally, it will allow us to compare evaluations of one’s own decision making with evaluations of another’s decision-making within a similar context.

q1.value: Katherine Pearl Hazen, Eve M. Brank

q2.value:
We expect to find a main effect of voice condition when participants are in the decision-making role. Participants that receive information about the audience's preferences will sanction audience members fewer tickets than those that do not receive information about the audience’s preference.   

We expect to find a within-group main effect of role on evaluations of fairness. Participants will evaluate their own decision making as more fair than they evaluate the decisions made about them. Additionally, we expect to find a mean effect of voice condition. Participants in the voice condition will perceive the decision-making process as more fair than those in the no voice condition. We further expect to find an interaction between role and voice condition. When in the role of the decision maker, the voice and no voice conditions will be evaluated as equally fair. However, in the role of the audience, those in the voice condition will evaluate the decision-making process as significantly more fair than the no voice condition. Further, for those in the audience role, this effect will be conditioned by the difference between the participant’s stated preference for their sanction and the sanction they received – the mean difference between the voice and no voice condition will be less for those with a larger difference between their stated preference and the sanction received.  

A three-way interaction is expected between role, voice condition, and group representation. When evaluating their own decision-making processes, those instructed to consider their interests as the same as their group members will evaluate their decision-making process without information about preferences as less fair than those instructed to consider their interests as distinct from their group members’ interests. The more closely the participants consider their interests and their group members’ interests, the greater the mean difference between voice conditions will be on perceptions of fairness. A closer group representation will reduce the differences between voice evaluations when participants are decision-makers and when they are the audience.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q5.value: The research assistants running the study will know which role the participants are assigned to after the random assignment occurs. After testing for order effects, the order of assignment to the with-in group condition will be blind.

question.value:
Participants and designs. This study will be a 2 (role: Deputy Research Assistant (DRA), participant (within-group factor)) x 2 (voice: voice, no voice) x 3 (group representation instruction: individual, 1 group, 2 groups) mixed-factor experimental design. The role will be a counterbalanced within-group factor while voice and group representation instruction will be between-group factors. Additionally, when in the participant condition, participants will be randomly assigned to lose one or four lottery tickets. The dependent variable of interest is the adapted Family Justice Scale (Fondacaro et al., 2002). Covariate measures in the Attitudes toward Authorities scale, social dominance orientation scale (Ho et al., 2015), the intergroup liking (Allophlia) scale, identity fusion scale, and demographic variables. 

Participants will be 420 undergraduate psychology students at a large midwestern university recruited through the student participant pool. Power analysis was conducted with G*Power (Faul et al., 2009) for repeated measures MANOVA for an interaction between the within- and between-subjects’ factors for six groups and two measurements. To detect an expected small effect (.20) with the desired power of .80 and alpha = .05, 327 participants are required. The sample estimate was increased by 20% for removal based on failed manipulation checks, failed attention checks, and missing responses, which is based on our experience with this participant pool in other in-lab projects conducted by the PIs. Participants will be compensated with 2-course credits.

Manipulation checks will ask about their group representation. One attention check will include their evaluations of their group-members behavior. One group member will not participate in the task for each group. Participants who evaluate that group member as having high quantity and quality participation will be examined for other careless responding behaviors, such as selecting only 5s or 7s on Likert-type scales (Berinsky, Margolis, & Sances, 2016; Curran 2016).

q7.value:
Randomization of the order of the role condition will occur on the individual level. Each participant will be assigned to one of two roles and those roles will be counter-balanced. Randomization to which role the participant is in first will be done through Qualtrics, which will randomly present one role assignment at a time, evenly. 

Randomization to the voice condition will occur at the task level. During each evaluation of the others in their groups, participants will be randomly assigned to the voice or no voice condition by evenly presenting each element once per participant. 

Randomization of the group representation will occur that the task level. When the participant receives their role instructions, they will also be randomly and evenly presented with one of the three group representation descriptions. 
Randomization of how many tickets participants will lose will occur once at the participant level when they are in the participant role. Simple randomization will present either one or four tickets to each participant evenly.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Procedures and materials. 
Data collection will through Slack and Qualtrics for a study ostensibly examining teamwork. Although participants will be told they are working in groups of four, they will be working independently. They will be told they are completing surveys about teamwork and based on their scores they will be placed into groups of four. In reality, they will continue to work independently, but in a chat with three scripted confederate participants using a similar methodology to research successfully completed by a recent lab member (Hoetger, 2018). Further, they will be told that within each group of four, the person who scored highest on the critical thinking task will be assigned as the superordinate group member, the Deputy Research Assistant (DRA). The surveys will measure attitudes toward authorities and social dominance orientation. The critical thinking task will be 15 GRE questions, including 10 considered easy and 5 considered difficult. Each participant will serve in the role of DRA and participant once in counterbalanced order. Following the initial surveys, participants will receive instructions about the role they have been assigned for the first task based on their responses to the initial. Each participant will be randomly assigned to receive one of three group identity instructions with their role instructions. The group identity instructions will instruct the participant to think of their group in one of three ways: as separate individuals, as a single unit, and as two groups (a group of participants with a DRA or a DRA with participants depending on their role) working toward a common goal. This manipulation is based on the identity fusion and dual identity literatures (Gaertner et al, 1998; Gaertner et al, 1990).

Participants will be instructed to complete a version of the winter problem, selecting items for a trip hosted by the university outdoor adventure center, via an online chat with their “group” in Slack. After completing the winter problem once, the participants will be assigned to a new group and complete another version of a similar task. Following each task, participants will make evaluations of themselves and their team. Participants will be told that they will receive five lottery tickets for a gift card for each task, however, that they could lose lottery tickets for failing to follow the instructions and rules. The DRA will evaluate each participant in their group and decide whether the participant will lose tickets and if so how many. Each participant will be randomly assigned to the voice or no voice condition for the instructions on compensation. In the voice condition, the DRA will receive input from each participant in their group about whether they should lose tickets and if so how many. The participants will be asked whether they should lose tickets and if so how many it should be. In the no voice condition, DRA will not receive sanction suggestions from participants. The participants will not be asked for a sanction suggestion. Finally, participants in the role of a participant will be randomly assigned to be told they have lost one ticket or four tickets. 

Participants will complete the adapted Family Justice Scale, the group identity measures, and the Allophilia scale about their group members. Participants will be thanked for their time, debriefed on the purpose of the study, and compensated for their participation.

q11.value: 420 undergraduate students at a large midwestern university will be recruited for this study. They will each complete the Family Justice Scale, identity fusion, and Allophilia scale as the Deputy Research Assistant and as a participant. Therefore, there will be 840 individual responses to each of these scales for within-group analyses examining the effect of the role. To examine the impact of the voice and group representation manipulations, there will 420 individual assignments within each role to examine the effects on perceptions of justice and group identity and 840 to examine the interactions between the role and each the voice and group representation manipulations for perceptions of decision making processes and group identity.

q12.value: Participants will be 420 undergraduate psychology students at a large midwestern university recruited through the student participant pool. Power analysis was conducted with G*Power (Faul et al., 2009) for repeated measures MANOVA for an interaction between the within- and between-subjects’ factors for six groups and two measurements. To detect an expected small effect (.20) with the desired power of .80 and alpha = .05, 327 participants are required. The sample estimate was increased by 20% for removal based on failed manipulation checks, failed attention checks, and missing responses, which is based on our experience with this participant pool in other in-lab projects conducted by the PIs.

question.value:
We manipulated the order of the role participants were instructed to be in with their groups. The two levels for this categorical variable are DRA, Participant and Participant, DRA. 

We manipulated voice when participants were in the participant and the DRA role. Participants were randomly presented with the opportunity to tell their DRA whether and how much they would be sanctioned. The two levels of this categorical variable are voice and no voice. Participants were randomly presented with the sanctioning preferences of each participant or not. The two levels of this categorical variable are voice and no voice. 

We manipulated how participants were instructed to think about their group. The three levels of this categorical variable are individual, group, two groups (role and group). 

We manipulated how many lottery tickets participants were told they lost when in the participant role. The two levels of this categorical variable are one and four.

Social dominance orientation (SDO) scale (SDO7) (Ho et al., 2015; Pratto et al., 1994) measures support for inequality between social groups, but not ingroup dominance over outgroups. Participants indicate the extent to which they support 16 items on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly oppose, 7 = strongly favor). SDO7 conceptualizes SDO as comprised of two subdimensions, with half the items on each subscale framed in the positive (pro-traits) and half in the negative (con-traits): the dominance (SDO-D) subdimension and the egalitarianism (SDO-E) subdimension. Con-traits are reversed coded to calculate mean subscale scores for each dimension, with higher scores meaning the participants are more in favor of group dominance. 

Social attitudes consistent with support for and willingness to comply with authority figures will be measured with the Attitudes Toward Authority Scale (ATA) (Varley, Votruba, & Shiota, in progress). The ATA is comprised of 16 items across four subscales measuring attitudes toward supporting and complying with authority figures: submission to formal authority, challenging authority, inherent superiority, and support for traditional norms. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with each item on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). 

Participants will be instructed that they will receive five lottery tickets as compensation for their time. Participants in the DRA role will be instructed that part of their role is to enforce the rules of the game to ensure the task is completed without problems. Therefore, if someone breaks a rule, they will have the ability to remove lottery tickets as a penalty for the rule breaking. At the end of the study they will be asked to report how many lottery tickets each member of their group is to be penalized. A voice instrumentality score will be calculated based on the proportional match between the voice expressed by the group members (always that they do not think they should lose lottery tickets as a penalty) and what the DRA actually decides their participants should receive. This design is a variation of the design used in the justice literature that asks the audience to respond to (un)fair treatment in the form of compensation (Folger & Konovsky, 1989; Margalit et al., unpublished manuscript) and voice instrumentality in deciding new activities for a university or work place activity (Avery & Quinones, 2002; Cornelis et al., 2013; Folger et al., 1979; de Vries et al., 2012). When participants are in the participant role they will be told they are being penalized and receiving fair (minus 1 lottery ticket) or unfair (minus 4 lottery tickets) treatment. 

Participants will complete an adapted version of the Family Justice Scale (Fondacaro et al., 2002) to evaluate their own and the Deputy Research Assistant's decision-making procedures. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with 36 items on a 5-point scale, 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). The Process Control, Voice, Neutrality, Dignity/Respect, Trust, and Global Fairness subscales will be included. A mean scale score will be calculated for each subscale. 

The Allophilia scale (Alfieri & Marta, 2011; Pittinsky, Rosenthal, & Montoya, 2011) will measure outgroup liking as conceptualized to include having positive feelings toward the group (affection), being comfortable around the outgroup (comfort), a sense of sharing something and belonging with the outgroup (kinship), seeking contact with the outgroup (engagement), and having a favorable impression toward the outgroup (enthusiasm). The scale consists of 17-items that participants rate on a 6-point agreement scale (1 = strongly disagree; 6 = strongly agree). 

Participants will indicate how they think of themselves in relation to the other members of their group on a series of items using five circles that overlap to varying degrees to measure identity fusion (Swann et al., 2009). Additionally, three questions will assess the extent to which participants feel the leader and the team are part of the same group: “Do you think that team leaders and team members are all members of the same group,” “On this team, there are not team leaders and team members, but only members of the team,” and “It is possible to say that team members and team leaders of this task are on the same team.” The degree of overlap will be used as a manipulation check on the group identity manipulation and measure of identity overlap.

The study hypotheses will be tested with descriptive statistics, analysis of variance, and moderated-mediation analyses. Preliminary and ANOVA analyses will be conducted in SPSS 26. Mediation and moderated-mediation analyses will be conducted in MPlus 7. Preliminary analyses, including descriptive statistics and correlations, will be used to assess normality and fit for factorial ANOVA and mediation. 

The study is a mixed-factorial design with one within-group factor (role) and two between-group factors (voice and group representation). Mixed-group factorial analysis of variance will be used to test the research hypotheses that participants will evaluate their own decision-making and others’ decision-making processes by examining main effects and interaction effects of the conditions on evaluations of fairness and the Family Justice Scale subscales. Additionally, it will examine the main effects and interaction effects of voice condition and group representation on worker compensation. Finally, the main effects and interaction effects of the conditions on the Allophilia will be examined.   

Next, structural equation modeling will be used to compare evaluations of the decision-making processes of Deputy Research Assistant and participants. The structural model will be used with bootstrapped analysis (Shrout & Bolger, 2002) to test the modeled indirect effects of voice condition on evaluations of fairness through perceptions of voice, neutrality, trust, and respect. The moderating effect of group-representation condition on the indirect effects mediating the effect of voice condition on perceptions of fairness will be examined. Additionally, the moderating effect of group identity on the effect of affect toward the other group members on the evaluations of fairness will also be examined. The bootstrap approach maximizes statistical power through resampling while minimizing the risk of Type 1 errors and creates confidence intervals (CI’s) through empirical approximation of sampling distributions of indirect effects. Nonparametric resampling methods (bias-correct bootstrap) with 5000 samples drawn to derive the 95% CI’s will be used for the modeled indirect effect of the procedural justice and outcome conditions on global fairness. 

The same analyses will then be repeated for participants while in the participant condition as well as in the DRA condition. The specific indirect effects of each condition will be examined and compared in magnitude and direction for the fairness evaluations as well as for compensation decisions.

registration_responses.q1: Katherine Pearl Hazen, Eve M. Brank
registration_responses.q2:
We expect to find a main effect of voice condition when participants are in the decision-making role. Participants that receive information about the audience's preferences will sanction audience members fewer tickets than those that do not receive information about the audience’s preference.   

We expect to find a within-group main effect of role on evaluations of fairness. Participants will evaluate their own decision making as more fair than they evaluate the decisions made about them. Additionally, we expect to find a mean effect of voice condition. Participants in the voice condition will perceive the decision-making process as more fair than those in the no voice condition. We further expect to find an interaction between role and voice condition. When in the role of the decision maker, the voice and no voice conditions will be evaluated as equally fair. However, in the role of the audience, those in the voice condition will evaluate the decision-making process as significantly more fair than the no voice condition. Further, for those in the audience role, this effect will be conditioned by the difference between the participant’s stated preference for their sanction and the sanction they received – the mean difference between the voice and no voice condition will be less for those with a larger difference between their stated preference and the sanction received.  

A three-way interaction is expected between role, voice condition, and group representation. When evaluating their own decision-making processes, those instructed to consider their interests as the same as their group members will evaluate their decision-making process without information about preferences as less fair than those instructed to consider their interests as distinct from their group members’ interests. The more closely the participants consider their interests and their group members’ interests, the greater the mean difference between voice conditions will be on perceptions of fairness. A closer group representation will reduce the differences between voice evaluations when participants are decision-makers and when they are the audience.
registration_responses.q3: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q4: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q5: The research assistants running the study will know which role the participants are assigned to after the random assignment occurs. After testing for order effects, the order of assignment to the with-in group condition will be blind.
registration_responses.q7:
Randomization of the order of the role condition will occur on the individual level. Each participant will be assigned to one of two roles and those roles will be counter-balanced. Randomization to which role the participant is in first will be done through Qualtrics, which will randomly present one role assignment at a time, evenly. 

Randomization to the voice condition will occur at the task level. During each evaluation of the others in their groups, participants will be randomly assigned to the voice or no voice condition by evenly presenting each element once per participant. 

Randomization of the group representation will occur that the task level. When the participant receives their role instructions, they will also be randomly and evenly presented with one of the three group representation descriptions. 
Randomization of how many tickets participants will lose will occur once at the participant level when they are in the participant role. Simple randomization will present either one or four tickets to each participant evenly.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: 420 undergraduate students at a large midwestern university will be recruited for this study. They will each complete the Family Justice Scale, identity fusion, and Allophilia scale as the Deputy Research Assistant and as a participant. Therefore, there will be 840 individual responses to each of these scales for within-group analyses examining the effect of the role. To examine the impact of the voice and group representation manipulations, there will 420 individual assignments within each role to examine the effects on perceptions of justice and group identity and 840 to examine the interactions between the role and each the voice and group representation manipulations for perceptions of decision making processes and group identity.
registration_responses.q12: Participants will be 420 undergraduate psychology students at a large midwestern university recruited through the student participant pool. Power analysis was conducted with G*Power (Faul et al., 2009) for repeated measures MANOVA for an interaction between the within- and between-subjects’ factors for six groups and two measurements. To detect an expected small effect (.20) with the desired power of .80 and alpha = .05, 327 participants are required. The sample estimate was increased by 20% for removal based on failed manipulation checks, failed attention checks, and missing responses, which is based on our experience with this participant pool in other in-lab projects conducted by the PIs.
registration_responses.q23: This study was originally planned for in-lab, in-person data collection. However, due to the limitations in data collection during COVID-19, data collection was put entirely online.
registration_responses.q6.question:
Participants and designs. This study will be a 2 (role: Deputy Research Assistant (DRA), participant (within-group factor)) x 2 (voice: voice, no voice) x 3 (group representation instruction: individual, 1 group, 2 groups) mixed-factor experimental design. The role will be a counterbalanced within-group factor while voice and group representation instruction will be between-group factors. Additionally, when in the participant condition, participants will be randomly assigned to lose one or four lottery tickets. The dependent variable of interest is the adapted Family Justice Scale (Fondacaro et al., 2002). Covariate measures in the Attitudes toward Authorities scale, social dominance orientation scale (Ho et al., 2015), the intergroup liking (Allophlia) scale, identity fusion scale, and demographic variables. 

Participants will be 420 undergraduate psychology students at a large midwestern university recruited through the student participant pool. Power analysis was conducted with G*Power (Faul et al., 2009) for repeated measures MANOVA for an interaction between the within- and between-subjects’ factors for six groups and two measurements. To detect an expected small effect (.20) with the desired power of .80 and alpha = .05, 327 participants are required. The sample estimate was increased by 20% for removal based on failed manipulation checks, failed attention checks, and missing responses, which is based on our experience with this participant pool in other in-lab projects conducted by the PIs. Participants will be compensated with 2-course credits.

Manipulation checks will ask about their group representation. One attention check will include their evaluations of their group-members behavior. One group member will not participate in the task for each group. Participants who evaluate that group member as having high quantity and quality participation will be examined for other careless responding behaviors, such as selecting only 5s or 7s on Likert-type scales (Berinsky, Margolis, & Sances, 2016; Curran 2016).
registration_responses.q10.question:
Procedures and materials. 
Data collection will through Slack and Qualtrics for a study ostensibly examining teamwork. Although participants will be told they are working in groups of four, they will be working independently. They will be told they are completing surveys about teamwork and based on their scores they will be placed into groups of four. In reality, they will continue to work independently, but in a chat with three scripted confederate participants using a similar methodology to research successfully completed by a recent lab member (Hoetger, 2018). Further, they will be told that within each group of four, the person who scored highest on the critical thinking task will be assigned as the superordinate group member, the Deputy Research Assistant (DRA). The surveys will measure attitudes toward authorities and social dominance orientation. The critical thinking task will be 15 GRE questions, including 10 considered easy and 5 considered difficult. Each participant will serve in the role of DRA and participant once in counterbalanced order. Following the initial surveys, participants will receive instructions about the role they have been assigned for the first task based on their responses to the initial. Each participant will be randomly assigned to receive one of three group identity instructions with their role instructions. The group identity instructions will instruct the participant to think of their group in one of three ways: as separate individuals, as a single unit, and as two groups (a group of participants with a DRA or a DRA with participants depending on their role) working toward a common goal. This manipulation is based on the identity fusion and dual identity literatures (Gaertner et al, 1998; Gaertner et al, 1990).

Participants will be instructed to complete a version of the winter problem, selecting items for a trip hosted by the university outdoor adventure center, via an online chat with their “group” in Slack. After completing the winter problem once, the participants will be assigned to a new group and complete another version of a similar task. Following each task, participants will make evaluations of themselves and their team. Participants will be told that they will receive five lottery tickets for a gift card for each task, however, that they could lose lottery tickets for failing to follow the instructions and rules. The DRA will evaluate each participant in their group and decide whether the participant will lose tickets and if so how many. Each participant will be randomly assigned to the voice or no voice condition for the instructions on compensation. In the voice condition, the DRA will receive input from each participant in their group about whether they should lose tickets and if so how many. The participants will be asked whether they should lose tickets and if so how many it should be. In the no voice condition, DRA will not receive sanction suggestions from participants. The participants will not be asked for a sanction suggestion. Finally, participants in the role of a participant will be randomly assigned to be told they have lost one ticket or four tickets. 

Participants will complete the adapted Family Justice Scale, the group identity measures, and the Allophilia scale about their group members. Participants will be thanked for their time, debriefed on the purpose of the study, and compensated for their participation.
registration_responses.q14.question:
We manipulated the order of the role participants were instructed to be in with their groups. The two levels for this categorical variable are DRA, Participant and Participant, DRA. 

We manipulated voice when participants were in the participant and the DRA role. Participants were randomly presented with the opportunity to tell their DRA whether and how much they would be sanctioned. The two levels of this categorical variable are voice and no voice. Participants were randomly presented with the sanctioning preferences of each participant or not. The two levels of this categorical variable are voice and no voice. 

We manipulated how participants were instructed to think about their group. The three levels of this categorical variable are individual, group, two groups (role and group). 

We manipulated how many lottery tickets participants were told they lost when in the participant role. The two levels of this categorical variable are one and four.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Social dominance orientation (SDO) scale (SDO7) (Ho et al., 2015; Pratto et al., 1994) measures support for inequality between social groups, but not ingroup dominance over outgroups. Participants indicate the extent to which they support 16 items on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly oppose, 7 = strongly favor). SDO7 conceptualizes SDO as comprised of two subdimensions, with half the items on each subscale framed in the positive (pro-traits) and half in the negative (con-traits): the dominance (SDO-D) subdimension and the egalitarianism (SDO-E) subdimension. Con-traits are reversed coded to calculate mean subscale scores for each dimension, with higher scores meaning the participants are more in favor of group dominance. 

Social attitudes consistent with support for and willingness to comply with authority figures will be measured with the Attitudes Toward Authority Scale (ATA) (Varley, Votruba, & Shiota, in progress). The ATA is comprised of 16 items across four subscales measuring attitudes toward supporting and complying with authority figures: submission to formal authority, challenging authority, inherent superiority, and support for traditional norms. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with each item on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). 

Participants will be instructed that they will receive five lottery tickets as compensation for their time.
